- Review the answers in the excel spreadsheet for Domino

notes.title: Untitled 1
notes.excerpt: From an architecture perspective, using an AWS Route53 Resolver rule to forward DNS resolution for Azure private endpoints to the corresponding Azure DNS servers, and associating it with
notes.content:
From an architecture perspective, using an AWS Route53 Resolver rule to forward DNS resolution for Azure private endpoints to the corresponding Azure DNS servers, and associating it with the relevant VPC, is a valid and established cross-cloud pattern. This is appropriate where AWS workloads need to resolve Azure services exposed via private endpoints.

A few important conditions to note:

This applies only to workloads running inside a VPC associated with the resolver rule; it will not address components outside that scope.

The rule should be domain-specific and tightly scoped.

Standard change and approval processes (including AWS Account Owner approval) should be followed.

The dependency on cross-cloud private DNS resolution should be documented (e.g. Architecture Note or ADR).

Provided these conditions are met, I don‚Äôt see architectural concerns with proceeding using this approach.

Thanks,
Laura

notes.title: Personal Development plan in AZ 2025
notes.excerpt: Q1 (Jan‚ÄìMar 2025) Principal Architect ‚Äì Domino Data Lab Platform Upgrade (v5.9.2 ‚Üí v6.0.2) (Completed: 2025 03 14) Led the end to end architectural design, risk assessment, and
notes.content:
### **Q1 (Jan‚ÄìMar 2025)**

- **Principal Architect ‚Äì Domino Data Lab Platform Upgrade (v5.9.2 ‚Üí v6.0.2)** _(Completed: 2025-03-14)_  
    Led the end-to-end architectural design, risk assessment, and execution of the enterprise Domino upgrade to v6.0.2, ensuring compliance, scalability, and uninterrupted business-critical workloads. Collaborated with ETS, R&D IT, and the AI Factory team to validate architecture under the new Nexus control-plane model.
    
- **Principal Architect ‚Äì Terminology Lookup Service (TLS)** _(Blueprint delivery: 2025-02-28)_  
    Designed and led the enterprise **Terminology Lookup Service** architecture, enabling standardized terminology management and secure data interoperability across R&D and IT environments. Delivered the solution blueprint to support metadata governance and FAIR data principles.
    
- **Agentic AI Workshop Organizer** _(Delivered: 2025-03-26)_  
    Conceived, coordinated, and delivered a multi-site **Agentic AI Workshop** across Cambridge, Gothenburg, and Barcelona, engaging over **60+ participants**. Strengthened AstraZeneca‚Äôs NextGen Data Science community through hands-on exploration of AI agent frameworks and orchestration patterns.
    

---

### **Q2 (Apr‚ÄìJun 2025)**

- **Global Data Science Symposium ‚Äì Barcelona Workstream** _(Ongoing since 2025-04-01)_  
    Served on the core organizing committee for the Barcelona track of AstraZeneca‚Äôs **Global Data Science Symposium**, with a dedicated focus on **Agentic AI**. Led agenda definition, speaker selection, and logistics to maximise impact and knowledge exchange.
    
- **AI Tech Radar (Enterprise Architecture contribution)** _(Submitted: 2025-05-05)_  
    Updated AstraZeneca‚Äôs **AI Tech Radar**, incorporating feedback from global architects to highlight emerging frontiers and tools across AI, LLMOps, and agentic orchestration. Presented recommendations to EA leadership to guide strategic technology adoption.
    

---

### **Q3 (Jul‚ÄìSep 2025)**

- **Ragify Solution Blueprint ‚Äì Cybersecurity Approval** _(Approved: 2025-09-16)_  
    Authored and led the full **Ragify** Solution Blueprint, a reusable RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) capability aligned with Enterprise AI standards. Secured cybersecurity clearance and formal enterprise approval for deployment across business units.
    
- **TLS Solution Blueprint ‚Äì Cybersecurity Ticket Raised** _(Raised: 2025-09-15)_  
    Initiated the cybersecurity review process for **TLS**, ensuring proactive risk management and adherence to AstraZeneca‚Äôs corporate security and compliance standards.
    
- **GOLD Certificate ‚Äì ‚ÄúThriving in the Age of AI‚Äù Programme** _(Awarded: 2025-10-15)_  
    Earned a **GOLD certificate** in AstraZeneca‚Äôs _Thriving in the Age of AI_ programme, recognising leadership in advancing AI fluency and promoting responsible AI adoption across the enterprise.
    
- **Polaris AI Core Team ‚Äì Onboarding and Engagement** _(Onboarded: 2025-09-23)_  
    Joined the **Polaris AI Core working team**, collaborating with ETS, R&D IT, and Enterprise AI Architecture to define the architectural direction of AstraZeneca‚Äôs next-generation AI compute and storage platform. Contributed to governance alignment and use-case identification frameworks.
    

---

### **Q4 (Oct‚ÄìDec 2025)**

- **Polaris AI Core ‚Äì Use Case Discovery and Requirement Definition** _(Interviews conducted: 2025-10-01 ‚Üí 2025-11-08)_  
    Conducted **seven in-depth stakeholder interviews** across R&D and IT to identify candidate use cases for Polaris. Consolidated findings into a **master list of functional and technical requirements** that will guide the system‚Äôs initial release scope and future enhancements.
    
- **AI Accelerator Alignment** _(Initiated: 2025-11-10)_  
    Facilitated alignment discussions between **ETS, R&D IT, and Enterprise AI Architecture** to explore synergies between Polaris and AstraZeneca‚Äôs **AI Accelerator** programme. Initiated coordination with the AI Accelerator team to assess use cases that could benefit from Polaris‚Äô computational capacity.
    
- **Polaris Blueprint Input ‚Äì Architectural and Governance Alignment** _(Ongoing since 2025-10-15)_  
    Provided architectural inputs aligning Polaris with AstraZeneca‚Äôs **Enterprise AI Governance Framework** and cybersecurity controls. Defined evaluation criteria for compute-intensive AI workloads, ensuring readiness for compliance with the **EU AI Act**.

notes.title: Cheatsheet
notes.excerpt: 1Ô∏è‚É£ Opening & Self Introduction Who you are ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Laura L√≥pez Real, Enterprise AI Architect at AstraZeneca, responsible for the strategy and tooling that enable our mainframe and
notes.content:
## 1Ô∏è‚É£ Opening & Self-Introduction

- **Who you are**  
    ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Laura L√≥pez-Real, Enterprise AI Architect at AstraZeneca, responsible for the strategy and tooling that enable our mainframe and legacy modernization. I oversee architecture, compliance and tool selection for cloud-ready services.‚Äù
    
- **Reason for meeting**  
    ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre in early discovery on replatforming COBOL and PL/I workloads. I‚Äôm evaluating automated documentation and business-rule extraction to shorten analysis cycles and reduce dependency on scarce legacy expertise.‚Äù
    

---

## 2Ô∏è‚É£ What to Highlight from Your Context

- **Key initiative**: _Invest in Agentic-AI-centric tools that produce efficiency gains at the business level_  
    ‚Äì Link this to Swimm‚Äôs AI-generated documentation and reverse engineering.
    
- **Timeline**: Target shortlist within **6‚Äì9 months**; modernization target completion **~2026**.
    
- **Pain points**:
    
    - Incomplete or outdated code documentation.
        
    - High risk of knowledge loss as experts retire.
        
    - Need for traceable compliance and auditable code mapping.
        

---

## 3Ô∏è‚É£ Deeper Questions to Ask Swimm

Use these to get detailed, decision-ready insights:

**Technology & Capabilities**

- How does Swimm perform business-rule extraction on COBOL and PL/I?
    
- Can it automatically detect inter-module dependencies and data lineage for large, heterogeneous codebases?
    
- How accurate is the generated documentation vs. manual SME review? Any benchmarks?
    

**Integration & Workflow**

- How does Swimm integrate with existing tools (e.g., Git, Jira, ServiceNow) and CI/CD?
    
- Can it feed outputs into cloud-migration accelerators (e.g., AWS Mainframe Modernization, Azure Migrate)?
    

**Security & Compliance**

- How is sensitive business logic handled (on-prem vs. cloud deployment)?
    
- Can Swimm enforce versioning, audit trails and GDPR/PCI/NIS2/DORA requirements?
    

**Scalability & Performance**

- What is the largest codebase successfully documented (lines of code, number of modules)?
    
- Typical processing time and infrastructure requirements?
    

**Cost & ROI**

- Pricing model (per KLOC, per repository, or enterprise license)?
    
- Example ROI from comparable pharmaceutical or regulated enterprises.
    

**Support & Change Management**

- What onboarding/training is required for dev and architecture teams?
    
- Does Swimm assist in upskilling staff or providing SMEs for complex rule extraction?
    

---

## 4Ô∏è‚É£ Points to Emphasize in Discussion

- Swimm aligns with your **agentic-AI efficiency** initiative‚Äîautomation that replaces months of manual discovery.
    
- Stress need for **audit-ready, explainable outputs** to satisfy internal and external compliance.
    
- Highlight **multi-language complexity** (COBOL, PL/I, Java) and **global operations** as key selection criteria.
    

---

## 5Ô∏è‚É£ Close the Meeting Strong

- Summarize fit: ‚ÄúSwimm‚Äôs AI-based documentation seems aligned with our goals of accelerating replatforming and reducing dependency on scarce legacy expertise.‚Äù
    
- Next step: request a **technical deep dive or pilot** aligned with your 6‚Äì9 month evaluation window.
    

---

Would you like me to draft a **one-minute self-introduction script** that weaves these points into a natural opener you can read or memorize?

UI meeting on 2nd September, 2024
- Ufuk thinks that the solution might require having a document store that is accessible by the graph database (is it worth it to have a separate service running 
- Currently, the session information is saved in the local store (Browser cache), and this is a wider problem that they need to address. Moving this information away from the local store would also require having something like a document store.
- To address both issues, we at least would require:
    - A service that runs a document store
    - An API to query and interact with the document store
    - A policy to provide the right access
- Ufuk thinks that this task would require input from the Compose team, as we work more closely with the infrastructure behind the KGs

Write down the meeting notes from the meeting I had with Sathya and Stephen
- CI/CD pipeline

March 2024

notes.excerpt: Plan for Vulnerability analysis Domino provided a transparency report where they showed all the vulnerabilities of the new release (6.0.2). We shared this report with Kasanianthan, director of
notes.content:
Plan for Vulnerability analysis
Domino provided a transparency report where they showed all the vulnerabilities of the new release (6.0.2).
We shared this report with Kasanianthan, director of cyber security. We discussed the options to run a vulnerability assessment, raise the Required exceptions and get approval to deploy this latest version of Domino into production.

# Vulnerability Comparison Report: Domino 5.9.3 vs 6.0.2

## Summary

- Total vulnerabilities in version 5.9.3: **58**
- Total vulnerabilities in version 6.0.2: **720**
- Vulnerabilities only present in 5.9.3: **54**
- Vulnerabilities only present in 6.0.2: **713**
- Vulnerabilities common to both versions: **7**
## New Vulnerabilities Introduced in 6.0.2

The following high or critical vulnerabilities were introduced in Domino 6.0.2 and are not found in version 5.9.3:

- **CVE-2018-14721** (CVSS: 10.0, Severity: Critical): Found in quay.io/domino/spark-cluster-environment, Status: This service is part of Domino's 'extended' catalog, which includes services that Domino has no ability to control functional and security updates. Domino will continue to monitor for updates and apply when a fix is made available; Customers may choose to remove this optional feature if necessary. Additionally, Apache Spark's official security page does not list any known vulnerabilities for the service with this version : https://spark.apache.org/security.html

- **CVE-2018-14721** (CVSS: 10.0, Severity: Critical): Found in quay.io/domino/domino-spark-environment, Status: This service is part of Domino's 'extended' catalog, which includes services that Domino has no ability to control functional and security updates. Domino will continue to monitor for updates and apply when a fix is made available; Customers may choose to remove this optional feature if necessary. Additionally, Apache Spark's official security page does not list any known vulnerabilities for the service with this version : https://spark.apache.org/security.html

- **CVE-2018-14721** (CVSS: 10.0, Severity: Critical): Found in quay.io/domino/domino-spark-environment, Status: This service is part of Domino's 'extended' catalog, which includes services that Domino has no ability to control functional and security updates. Domino will continue to monitor for updates and apply when a fix is made available; Customers may choose to remove this optional feature if necessary. Additionally, Apache Spark's official security page does not list any known vulnerabilities for the service with this version : https://spark.apache.org/security.html

- **CVE-2024-41110** (CVSS: 9.9, Severity: Critical): Found in quay.io/domino/soci-controller, Status: This service is part of Domino's 'extended' catalog, which includes services that Domino has no ability to control functional and security updates. Domino will continue to monitor for updates and apply when a fix is made available; Customers may choose to remove this optional feature if necessary.

- **CVE-2018-19361** (CVSS: 9.8, Severity: Critical): Found in quay.io/domino/domino-spark-environment, Status: This service is part of Domino's 'extended' catalog, which includes services that Domino has no ability to control functional and security updates. Domino will continue to monitor for updates and apply when a fix is made available; Customers may choose to remove this optional feature if necessary. Additionally, Apache Spark's official security page does not list any known vulnerabilities for the service with this version : https://spark.apache.org/security.html

  

## Resolved or Removed Vulnerabilities in 6.0.2

These vulnerabilities were found in 5.9.3 but no longer appear in 6.0.2, suggesting they may have been resolved or removed:

- **CVE-2023-37903** (CVSS: 10.0, Severity: Critical): Previously impacted docker://domino/ai-hub-environment-images:project-hub-gpu5.8

docker://domino/ai-hub-environment-images:llm-inference5.8

- **CVE-2023-37466** (CVSS: 10.0, Severity: Critical): Previously impacted docker://domino/ai-hub-environment-images:project-hub-gpu5.8

docker://domino/ai-hub-environment-images:llm-inference5.8

- **CVE-2023-6018** (CVSS: 9.8, Severity: Critical): Previously impacted docker://domino/ai-hub-environment-images:project-hub-gpu5.8

docker://domino/ai-hub-environment-images:llm-inference5.8

- **CVE-2019-10202** (CVSS: 9.8, Severity: High): Previously impacted docker://domino/bitnami.spark:3.5.0-debian-11-r35-390110

- **CVE-2019-16224** (CVSS: 9.8, Severity: Critical): Previously impacted docker://domino/ingress-nginx.controller:v1.9.6-390065

Domino blueprint update
Questions for Rakesh: 
1. Are there any automated processes that uses personal credentials? In such a case, they can now migrate to ‚Äúservice accounts‚Äù for better security and auditing.

2. Introduced in [Domino v5.10 are Domino Service Accounts](https://docs.dominodatalab.com/en/latest/admin_guide/6921e5/domino-service-accounts/) as an alternative option to NPA API Keys for integrations. Admin role is required to manage this but it is a more secure and recommended way over non-personal accounts for service account integrations. Operational documentation will be created by the platform team to include a process for teams to request creation, review, modification, and revocation of these Service Accounts. -> Was this ever done?
3. 
4. New Governance Admin role. Was SysAdmin used for compliance tasks? clarify whether you will adopt the new role to reduce privilege overhead.

notes.path: Astrazeneca/AZ/EAIA Projects/AI Tech Radar 2025 ‚Äì Current and Emerging Trends in AI.md
notes.title: AI Tech Radar 2025 ‚Äì Current and Emerging Trends in AI
notes.excerpt: Slide 1: Introduction & Context The ideal audience for this presentation AZ colleagues from IT looking to align technology strategy with the latest AI trends. Purpose of this
notes.content:
## Slide 1: Introduction & Context

- The ideal audience for this presentation AZ colleagues from IT looking to align technology strategy with the latest AI trends.
    
- **Purpose of this Tech radar is  highlighting **current mainstream technologies**, **near-future trends**, and **experimental innovations**. We‚Äôll start with general AI trends and then delve into **real examples in pharma/life sciences**, bridging technical capabilities with industry use-cases.
    
- **Approach:** Cover ‚Äúboth worlds‚Äù ‚Äì the broad AI landscape and domain-specific impacts. Trends are grouped by time horizon (now, next, future) to inform strategic planning and adoption roadmaps.
    

## Slide 2: Key Current AI Trends (2024-2025)

- **Generative AI & Foundation Models:** Explosion of large AI models for text, image, and code generation (ChatGPT, DALL-E, etc.). _GenAI_ went mainstream in 2023 ‚Äì e.g. ChatGPT reached **100 million users in 2 months** (fastest consumer app ever reaching these numbers)[reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/technology/chatgpt-sets-record-fastest-growing-user-base-analyst-note-2023-02-01/#:~:text=Feb%201%20%28Reuters%29%20,a%20UBS%20study%20on%20Wednesday). Enterprises are racing to leverage this tech; by 2026, Gartner predicts **70% of new application development** will be influenced by generative AI[gartner.com](https://www.gartner.com/en/articles/gartner-top-10-strategic-technology-trends-for-2024#:~:text=)
    
- **AI Engineering (MLOps) at Scale:** Focus on operationalizing AI in production. Organizations are investing in **DataOps/MLOps pipelines** to deploy AI reliably and at scale. 
Gartner‚Äôs AI Hype Cycle highlights _AI engineering_ as critical for unifying data and model pipelines (from cloud to edge) which is the way to reach **coherent, enterprise-wide AI delivery**[seldon.io](https://www.seldon.io/the-significance-of-ai-engineering-in-the-gartner-hype-cycle/#:~:text=AI%20Engineering%20in%20the%20Hype,Cycle). 
In practice, this means building robust model **deployment, monitoring, and lifecycle management** to move from experimental pilots to stable AI services.
    
- **Responsible & Trustworthy AI:** Ensuring AI systems are **ethical, transparent, and secure** is a top priority (especially in regulated industries). Frameworks like **AI TRiSM** (Trust, Risk & Security Management) have emerged to govern AI models‚Äô fairness, reliability, and compliance[splunk.com](https://www.splunk.com/en_us/blog/learn/ai-trism-ai-trust-risk-security-management.html#:~:text=,such%20as). Organizations are implementing bias mitigation, explainability, and rigorous validation to build user trust and meet new AI regulations. (For example, the upcoming EU AI Act demands risk controls on AI applications.)
    
- **Edge AI and IoT Integration:** Increasing deployment of AI **closer to data sources** on devices and ‚Äúsmart‚Äù sensors. This enables real-time insights with low latency ‚Äì e.g. **AI on wearables and medical IoT** for health monitoring. Edge AI runs on smartphones, smartwatches, even lab equipment, processing data locally without constant cloud connectivity[ibm.com](https://www.ibm.com/think/topics/edge-vs-cloud-ai#:~:text=Edge%20AI%20refers%20to%20the,applications%20closer%20to%20data%20sources)[ibm.com](https://www.ibm.com/think/topics/edge-vs-cloud-ai#:~:text=Edge%20AI%20uses%20certain%20kinds,in%20the%20devices%20it%20powers). This trend reduces bandwidth costs and improves privacy, and is used in settings like manufacturing lines and remote patient monitoring (where instant analytics are critical).
    

## Slide 3: AI in Pharma & Life Sciences ‚Äì Real Use Cases

_AI in the lab: a scientist uses a microscope alongside an AI-driven robotic assistant (illustrative)._  
AI is already delivering tangible results in life sciences, transforming how new therapies are discovered, tested, and delivered. Traditionally conservative, pharma is now embracing AI to **accelerate R&D** and improve outcomes, with multiple real-world successes:

- **AI-Accelerated Drug Discovery & Design:** Pharmaceutical R&D is being sped up by AI-driven platforms. For example, UK startup _Exscientia_ used AI (its ‚ÄúCentaur Chemist‚Äù platform) to design a novel cancer drug that reached clinical trials in under **12 months**[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=Rise%20of%20AI,Platforms) ‚Äì dramatically faster than traditional timelines. Large pharma are also leveraging AI partnerships; _Pfizer_ teamed with AI companies (Tempus, CytoReason, Gero) to streamline drug discovery and even helped accelerate development of the COVID-19 antiviral **Paxlovid** using AI insights[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=Pfizer). These cases show AI reducing the cost and time of drug design by automating molecule generation and target identification.
    
- **Generative AI in R&D (Biology):** Advances like _DeepMind‚Äôs AlphaFold_ have revolutionized biology by predicting protein structures with high accuracy. AlphaFold solved >200 million protein structures and is used by over **1.2 million researchers** worldwide to tackle diseases (malaria, cancer, etc.)[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=opening%20doors%20to%20faster%2C%20more,accurate%20solutions). This generative AI for proteins accelerates target discovery and vaccine design. Looking ahead, new AI models can even **design entirely new proteins** not seen in nature (e.g. DeepMind‚Äôs ‚ÄúGenie‚Äù model)[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=But%20it%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20stop%20there,diseases%20like%20Alzheimer%E2%80%99s%20and%20cancer), opening the door to bespoke therapeutics.
    
- **Smarter Clinical Trials:** AI is optimizing clinical development by making trials faster and more efficient. One major hurdle ‚Äì patient recruitment ‚Äì is being tackled with AI algorithms that scan medical records to match patients to trials **in days instead of months**[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=This%20is%20a%20major%20win,a%20broader%20range%20of%20participants). For instance, an AI tool (_TrialGPT_) can automatically find eligible participants from health data[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=Recruiting%20the%20right%20patients%20has,recruitment%20but%20also%20helps%20ensure), helping to fill trials quicker (important since ~25% of studies fail due to under-enrollment[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=This%20is%20a%20major%20win,a%20broader%20range%20of%20participants)). AI is also used to adapt trial design on the fly (analyzing interim results) and even simulate control arms with ‚Äúdigital twins‚Äù of patient data, which in one Alzheimer‚Äôs study **cut required participants by 21%**[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=And%20here%E2%80%99s%20where%20things%20get,making%20it%20faster%20to%20bring). These innovations lead to faster approvals and cost savings.
    
- **AI in Diagnostics & Personalized Care:** In healthcare delivery, AI-driven diagnostics are improving accuracy and speed. For example, AI vision models can analyze radiology images to **detect tumors or abnormalities** that doctors might miss[infosys.com](https://www.infosys.com/iki/research/ai-business-value-radar2025-life-sciences.html#:~:text=to%20Phase%20III%20drug%20trials,and%20in%20regulatory%20review). Pharma companies like AstraZeneca are using AI (e.g. with partner Qure.ai) to interpret chest scans and identify diseases (such as lung fibrosis or kidney disease) earlier[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=AstraZeneca). Additionally, AI voice analysis and genomics AI are being explored for predictive diagnostics. This push towards precision medicine means treatments can be tailored to patients based on AI insights (e.g. predicting who will respond to a drug).
    
- **Operational Efficiency & Automation:** Beyond R&D, pharma companies are applying AI to manufacturing and supply chain operations. A great example is _Pfizer‚Äôs use of intelligent automation_ in its temperature-controlled supply chain ‚Äì AI systems monitor and adjust conditions in real time, reducing human error and ensuring quality in vaccine distribution[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=to%20a%20highly%20efficient%2C%20AI,system). Predictive maintenance AI models foresee equipment failures in factories to prevent downtime. Some firms are implementing **digital twins** of production lines to simulate and optimize processes before making physical changes[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=And%20here%E2%80%99s%20where%20things%20get,making%20it%20faster%20to%20bring). The result is higher efficiency, lower costs, and more reliable delivery of medicines.
    

## Slide 4: Emerging & Future AI Technologies

- **Autonomous AI Agents (‚ÄúAgentic AI‚Äù):** The next frontier is AI systems that can **act autonomously** to perform tasks or make decisions in collaboration with other AI agents. Rather than single-response chatbots, these are goal-driven _AI agents_ that carry out multi-step operations (e.g. automatically research a topic, then draft a report, then refine based on feedback). Hype around prototypes like AutoGPT emerged in 2024. Enterprises are intrigued ‚Äì over **25% of organizations are already exploring agentic AI** on a significant scale[deloitte.com](https://www.deloitte.com/us/en/what-we-do/capabilities/applied-artificial-intelligence/content/state-of-generative-ai-in-enterprise.html#:~:text=match%20at%20L659%20relate%20to,while%20remembering%20what%20they%E2%80%99ve%20done). The vision is that such agents could reliably handle complex workflows by processing multi-modal data and coordinating with other agents (while remembering past actions)[deloitte.com](https://www.deloitte.com/us/en/what-we-do/capabilities/applied-artificial-intelligence/content/state-of-generative-ai-in-enterprise.html#:~:text=relate%20to%20agentic%20AI,while%20remembering%20what%20they%E2%80%99ve%20done). This is still early-stage, but pilot use-cases (like AI assistants for IT support, or autonomous research agents in labs) are under experimentation.
    
- **Federated Learning & Privacy-Preserving AI:** As data privacy regulations grow, new techniques allow AI models to train on **distributed data** without aggregating it in one place. _Federated learning (FL)_ is an emerging approach where an algorithm learns from data kept locally at hospitals or institutions, sending only model updates (not raw patient data). This enables collaborative analytics across silos while protecting sensitive information[nature.com](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41746-025-01836-3?error=cookies_not_supported&code=fa8479d7-ef09-4535-a2b5-c4216e3101bf#:~:text=governance%20and%20ethical%20challenges4%20,the%20data%2034%2C6%20%2C%2036). In healthcare, FL is already used for things like predicting hospitalizations or improving cancer detection by learning from multiple hospitals‚Äô data **without sharing patient records**[nature.com](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41746-025-01836-3?error=cookies_not_supported&code=fa8479d7-ef09-4535-a2b5-c4216e3101bf#:~:text=who%20continues%20this%20process%20with,other%20data%20owners9). Expect wider adoption of FL and related privacy-enhancing technologies (secure multi-party compute, homomorphic encryption) so that AI can comply with strict data protection laws while still gaining insights from large-scale data.
    
- **AI-Designed Molecules & Proteins (Generative Biology):** Today‚Äôs generative AI is not just about text and images ‚Äì it‚Äôs beginning to generate _biology_. We discussed AlphaFold‚Äôs impact; the next step is AI that proposes new drug molecules or protein therapies from scratch. Early success stories (Exscientia, Insilico Medicine) hint at the potential: Insilico‚Äôs AI-designed drug for pulmonary fibrosis entered human trials in just 2.5 years[insilico.com](https://insilico.com/phase1#:~:text=From%20Start%20to%20Phase%201,of%20February%2C%202022%2C%20Insilico). Researchers are now using generative models to invent proteins with desired functions (enzymes, antibodies) in a fraction of the time of lab experiments. For example, the _Genie_ model can **design novel proteins** that meet specific goals (e.g. binding to a virus)[coherentsolutions.com](https://www.coherentsolutions.com/insights/artificial-intelligence-in-pharmaceuticals-and-biotechnology-current-trends-and-innovations#:~:text=But%20it%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20stop%20there,diseases%20like%20Alzheimer%E2%80%99s%20and%20cancer). This experimental area could radically speed up vaccine and drug development ‚Äì envision AI proposing a cure for a disease by virtually screening and ‚Äúinventing‚Äù the biological agent. It‚Äôs early days, but progress here is accelerating.
    
- **Quantum Computing for AI (Future Outlook):** Looking a bit farther out, quantum computing promises to **turbocharge AI capabilities**. Quantum Machine Learning (QML) is still mostly in research labs, but it could enable breakthroughs especially in drug discovery and precision medicine. Quantum computers can theoretically analyze complex molecular interactions or huge data states exponentially faster. A recent review suggests quantum methods have the potential to deliver _faster, more accurate diagnostics and personalized treatments_ by handling computation beyond classical limits[arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2502.18639#:~:text=,However%2C%20integrating%20quantum%20technologies). For instance, quantum-generated models might explore chemical space more efficiently to find new drug candidates[nature.com](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41587-024-02526-3#:~:text=,KRAS%20inhibitors%20for%20cancer%20therapy). Major tech firms and pharma companies (IBM, Google, Roche, etc.) are investing in QML experiments. While practical quantum AI applications may be a few years away, this is a key ‚Äúwatching brief‚Äù on the radar ‚Äì a future **game-changer** if technical challenges (qubit stability, error correction) are overcome.
    

## Slide 5: Conclusion & Next Steps

- **AI as a Strategic Imperative:** The rapid developments in AI ‚Äì from today‚Äôs generative AI to tomorrow‚Äôs autonomous agents ‚Äì mean that AI is now central to business innovation. The enterprise architects‚Äô role is to ensure the organization can **leverage these technologies** effectively. This includes aligning AI initiatives with business goals (e.g. faster drug launches, better customer engagement) and keeping an eye on emerging tech that could provide a competitive edge. Not every hyped innovation will pan out, but ignoring AI trends is not an option.
    
- **Adopt, Trial, Assess:** Treat this tech radar as guidance for action. **Current ‚ÄúAdopt‚Äù items** (like generative AI and robust MLOps practices) should be integrated into your IT roadmaps now ‚Äì e.g. deploying an internal LLM for knowledge management, or automating model deployment pipelines. **Near-future ‚ÄúTrial‚Äù items** (like federated learning or agentic AI) warrant experimentation through pilots or proofs-of-concept in the next 12-18 months, so your organization builds competence early. **Future ‚ÄúAssess‚Äù items** (quantum AI, etc.) should be monitored and studied via R&D partnerships or innovation teams, until they mature enough for investment.
    
- **Enablement and Governance:** To succeed with AI at scale, enterprises must invest in the **foundations** ‚Äì data quality, infrastructure, and people. High-performing companies in life sciences pair heavy AI investment with digital transformation and training[infosys.com](https://www.infosys.com/iki/research/ai-business-value-radar2025-life-sciences.html#:~:text=,in%20terms%20of%20success%20rate). Upskilling your workforce (data scientists, domain experts) and fostering an AI-ready culture is crucial[infosys.com](https://www.infosys.com/iki/research/ai-business-value-radar2025-life-sciences.html#:~:text=,lead%20to%20even%20stronger%20results). Equally important is strengthening AI governance: put in place the policies (as in AI TRiSM) to ensure models are audited for bias, data is managed ethically, and regulatory compliance is maintained. By preparing now ‚Äì improving data pipelines, addressing change management, and instituting responsible AI frameworks ‚Äì enterprise architects can help unlock AI‚Äôs full business value while mitigating risks. **In summary**, stay pragmatic but forward-looking: capitalize on what AI can do today, and architect the organization to be ready for what‚Äôs coming next. [infosys.com](https://www.infosys.com/iki/research/ai-business-value-radar2025-life-sciences.html#:~:text=,in%20terms%20of%20success%20rate)

notes.content:
SM is a data management platform for **environmental socilal and governance** data
The solution that enables
- Recording: capture and record data. Enable GAP detection in data and request data to the correspondent Data Stewards.
- Reporting: in support to decision making (dashboards)
- Reduce: Suggesting measures on how to reduce  the impact for sustainability purposes.

Ramon estimates that SM would take about 8-12 weeks to be configured in AstraZeneca.

SM provides data connectors, analytical capabilities and reporting dashboards., scoreboards etc. (but my view is that this is not an advantage as Power APPs also offer these functionality)

**Advantages over  "Vanilla" Power Apps (Power BI and Power Query)**
- The Sustainability Manager data model has been tested and is used by very large organisations.
- The main advantage over vanilla Power NO is in terms Total cost of ownership and time to market
- Their engineers estimate that it would take between 8 to 12 months to replicate this solution 

The Generative AI models used by SM are OpenAI models that have been fine-tuned. They are served through Copilot and Copilot studio.

Multinational companies usually deploy one instance of Sustainability manager for the whole enterprise

notes.path: Astrazeneca/Pet/Ontoverse/In general, what do you recommend to speed up the pipeline.md
notes.title: In general, what do you recommend to speed up the pipeline
notes.excerpt: Below are the biggest wins we‚Äôve seen when teams build ‚Äúgraph + D3 + React‚Äù UIs like yours. I‚Äôve grouped them from ‚Äúfastest to wire up‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúlarger
notes.content:
Below are the **biggest wins we‚Äôve seen when teams build ‚Äúgraph + D3 + React‚Äù UIs like yours.**  
I‚Äôve grouped them from **‚Äúfastest to wire-up‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúlarger refactors.‚Äù** Pick the ones that fit your schedule.

||Recommendation|Why it helps|How to do it quickly|
|---|---|---|---|

|**1**|**Memoize expensive selectors** ‚Äì especially the ones that flatten `paperNodes`, build `cloneNodes`, and run `getFiltered / getSortedPapers`.|Zustand‚Äôs store updates on _every dispatch_; without `shallow` or `memo`, derived arrays are rebuilt and trigger re-renders.|`ts const allPapers = useRichDataStore(state => state.paperNodes, shallow)` and wrap heavy calculations in `useMemo` **and** `useDeferredValue` (React 18).|

|**2**|**De-bounce D3 zoom > URL writing**|You already debounce to 500 ms, but still run on **mousemove** (fires every frame). Check `event.sourceEvent?.type === 'zoom'` _instead_ of `mousemove`.||

|**3**|**Strip all `console.log` & dev-only imports in prod**|Logs + source-map parsing cost ~30‚Äì70 ms per mount.|Vite: `build.rollupOptions.treeshake = { annotations: true }` + `vite-plugin-strip`.|
|**4**|**Pre-compute graph layout & contours offline**|Contour calculation is your top stack-trace. Do it once (in Node.js or a small cloud function) ‚Üí save JSON.|CLI script: `node scripts/buildLayout.js`. Load the JSON straight into the client.|
|**5**|**Move heavy crunching (contours, large filters) to a Web Worker**|Main thread stays free, React feels snappy even on 1 MB graphs.|`comlink` + `vite-plugin-worker` ‚Äì expose `buildContours(points)` from the worker, return GeoJSON paths.|
|**6**|**Virtualise the graph itself** (canvas layers)|SVG hurts when ‚â•2 k nodes. A static `<canvas>` for edges + highlighted `<svg>` layer for selected nodes gives a 5-10√ó boost.|Keep existing D3 code, but switch `selection.select('canvas')` for the edge links; only selected / hovered nodes remain in SVG.|
|**7**|**Code-split right-drawer & filter panel**|They‚Äôre tree-shaken but still inside the first JS chunk.|`const FilterPanel = lazy(() => import('./FilterPanel'))` + `<Suspense>`.|
|**8**|**Use `React.Profiler` + the DevTools flame-graph**|Find the slowest commit phases; you‚Äôll usually see `PaperItem` or `TopicChip` rerendering too often.|Wrap suspected components in `<Profiler id="PaperItem" onRender={‚Ä¶} />`.|
|**9**|**Incremental TypeScript build in CI**|`tsc --build` with project references cuts 40-70 % from a cold build.||
|**10**|**Turn on the Vite esbuild pre-bundle cache**|`optimizeDeps.persist = true` (default), but make sure the cache folder isn‚Äôt nuked by Docker layers.||

---

### Quick illustration of the _single_ biggest hot-path right now

```txt
renderContoursByDensity ‚ü∂ contourDensity()       ‚Üê  ~250 ms
                          ‚ü∂ geoPath()            ‚Üê  ~120 ms
Graph re-init on zoom     ‚ü∂ initGraph()          ‚Üê  ~220 ms
```

If you _pre-compute_ the contour paths and ship them as SVG `<path>` strings, the browser just paints them ‚Üí ~10 ms instead of ~400 ms.

---

### Low-hanging micro-optimisations

- **`findCloneNodes`** ‚Äì return early if `cloneNodes.length === 0`.
    
- **`getCirclesBoundingBox`** ‚Äì cache result per topic cluster key.
    
- **`Virtuoso` height** ‚Äì instead of recalculating every render, memoise with `useMemo([filteredAndSortedPapers.length])`.
    

---

**Start with 1‚Äì4; you‚Äôll feel the UI snap immediately.**  
When you have a full sprint, tackle 5‚Äì6 for long-term scalability. Good luck, and ping me when you need deeper profiling!

notes.title: Plan for WebGL
notes.excerpt: Perfect. Here's the plan to transform your graph data into a format suitable for Deck.gl using performant force layout algorithms , allowing you to experiment with different layout
notes.content:
Perfect. Here's the plan to **transform your graph data into a format suitable for Deck.gl using performant force-layout algorithms**, allowing you to experiment with different layout styles efficiently.

---

## ‚úÖ **Goal**

Convert `papers2.json` (a hierarchical JSON with ~53.5K nodes and 259K edges) into a flat list of nodes and links **with `(x, y)` coordinates**, suitable for rendering in **Deck.gl** using **ScatterplotLayer** and **LineLayer**.

---

## üß† Step-by-Step Plan

### 1. **Choose the optimal layout engine**

For large-scale layout computation, the most performant libraries are:

|Library|Language|Pros|Notes|
|---|---|---|---|
|**`graphology` + `graphology-layout-forceatlas2`**|JS|Best Node.js support, ForceAtlas2 GPU optimized|‚ö° Best for web compatibility|
|**`fa2`** (from `fa2`)|Python|Ultra-fast ForceAtlas2 on CPU|Good for precomputing offline|
|**`openord` / `graph-tool`**|Python/C++|Best for community detection and huge graphs|Harder to install; pre-processing only|
|**`networkit`**|Python|Optimized for large graphs, Force-directed & others|Advanced, good for experimentation|

üí° **Recommendation:** Start with **Python + fa2** (offline fast layout) and export results for Deck.gl.

---

### 2. **Data Transformation Script**

We'll:

- Load `papers2.json`
    
- Extract flat `nodes[]` and `edges[]`
    
- Run ForceAtlas2 layout
    
- Save `.json` with positions
    

---

### 3. **Python Script (Using `fa2`)**

Install required packages:

`pip install networkx fa2`

Now run this script:

```python
import json import networkx as nx 
from fa2 import ForceAtlas2  

# Load your data with open("papers2.json") as f:     
data = json.load(f)  
# Recursive function to extract all nodes def extract_nodes(node, nodes):     
nodes[node['id']] = node     

for child in node.get("children", []):         
	extract_nodes(child, nodes)  
	# Build node map 

nodes_map = {} extract_nodes(data["treeNode"], nodes_map)  

# Build graph 
G = nx.Graph()  
# Add nodes 
for node_id, node in nodes_map.items():     
	G.add_node(node_id)  
	
# Add edges for edge in data["edges"]:     
G.add_edge(edge["source"], edge["target"])  

# Run ForceAtlas2 
forceatlas2 = ForceAtlas2(     
	outboundAttractionDistribution=True,     
	linLogMode=False,     
	adjustSizes=False,     
	edgeWeightInfluence=1.0,     
	jitterTolerance=1.0,     
	barnesHutOptimize=True,     
	barnesHutTheta=1.2,     
	scalingRatio=2.0,     
	strongGravityMode=False,     
	gravity=1.0,     
	verbose=True,
	)  
positions = forceatlas2.forceatlas2_networkx_layout(
		G, pos=None, iterations=3000
	)  
	
# Output for Deck.gl 
nodes = [
	{"id": node_id, "x": pos[0], "y": pos[1]} for node_id, pos in positions.items()
	] 
edges = [
	{"source": u, "target": v} for u, v in G.edges()
	]  
	
with open("graph_deckgl.json", "w") as f:     
	json.dump({"nodes": nodes, "edges": edges}, f, indent=2)`

```
---

## üß© React + Deck.gl Component Sketch

Once you have `graph_deckgl.json`:

tsx

```js
import DeckGL from '@deck.gl/react'; 
import { ScatterplotLayer, LineLayer } from '@deck.gl/layers';
function GraphViewer({ data }) {   

	const nodes = data.nodes;   
	const edges = data.edges;    
	
	const nodeLayer = new ScatterplotLayer({     
		id: 'nodes',     
		data: nodes,     
		getPosition: d => [d.x, d.y],     
		getRadius: 10,     
		getFillColor: [0, 128, 255],     
		pickable: true   
	});    
	
	const edgeLayer = new LineLayer({     
		id: 'edges',     
		data: edges,     
		getSourcePosition: d => {       
			const source = nodes.find(n => n.id === d.source);       
			return [source.x, source.y];     
			},     
		getTargetPosition: d => {       
			const target = nodes.find(n => n.id === d.target);
			return [target.x, target.y];     
			},     
		getColor: [200, 200, 200],     
		getWidth: 1   });    
		return (     
			<DeckGL       
				initialViewState={
					{ longitude: 0, latitude: 0, zoom: 0 }
				}
				controller={true}       
				layers={[edgeLayer, nodeLayer]}     
				/>   
			); 
	}
```

---

## üîÑ Next Steps

1. Run the Python layout script and check output
    
2. Load `graph_deckgl.json` in the React Deck.gl component
    
3. Experiment with `ForceAtlas2`, `Fruchterman-Reingold`, or `YifanHu` layouts for better maps
    
4. Optional: Normalize coordinates for zoom/pan compatibility
    

Would you like me to generate the layout now with the `papers2.json` you provided?

##### You said:

okay that's one but I also want a script that uses the already existing coordenates

###### ChatGPT said:

It looks like the dataset doesn't contain consistent `x` and `y` coordinate fields under the common keys (`x`, `y`, or `props.layout.x`). To proceed, I‚Äôll inspect a few sample nodes from the tree structure to determine where (if anywhere) the coordinates might be stored.

Let me fetch a few example nodes now.

Sample Tree Nodes

|typeNumber|id|paperNode|topicNode|
|---|---|---|---|
|1|247|False|True|
|1|248|False|True|
|1|249|False|True|

The dataset does **not** contain precomputed `x` and `y` coordinates for the nodes ‚Äî at least not in the main fields or inside `props`.

Instead, you'll need to **compute the layout yourself** using a layout algorithm like ForceAtlas2, then export the resulting `{ id, x, y }` for Deck.gl.

Would you like me to:

1. Generate a Python script that computes coordinates using **ForceAtlas2 via NetworkX + fa2** and writes the output as JSON?
    
2. Show how to plug that into a **React + Deck.gl scatterplot layer**?
    

Let‚Äôs proceed with step 1 if that‚Äôs OK with you.

##### You said:

so how does it work in the current UI?

###### ChatGPT said:

Great question ‚Äî let's break down how the current Ontoverse UI (based on the `HierarchyGraph.ts` and `GraphGridLayout.ts`) **computes and assigns coordinates to the nodes**:

---

### ‚úÖ Current Coordinate Assignment Strategy (in Ontoverse UI)

The UI uses **D3‚Äôs `pack()` layout algorithm** to compute node positions. Here's how it works:

#### 1. **D3 Hierarchy Construction**

ts

CopyEdit

`const rootNode = hierarchy(graphData.treeNode);`

This builds a D3 `HierarchyNode` tree from the nested topic ‚Üí subtopic ‚Üí paper structure.

#### 2. **Node Value Assignment**

Each node is assigned a `.value` used to influence its relative size in the layout:

ts

CopyEdit

`rootNode.sum((d) => (d as { value: number }).value * 10);`

This "weight" affects the final radius (`r`) of each node.

#### 3. **D3 Pack Layout: Assigning x/y/r**

ts

CopyEdit

`pack<TreeNode>().size([3840, 2160])(rootNode);`

This assigns `x`, `y`, and `r` to every node based on a **circle packing algorithm**, trying to prevent overlap.

---

### üß† Implications

- The layout is deterministic and based on hierarchical containment (i.e. "packed bubbles").
    
- The center of each topic contains its children (like subtopics or papers).
    
- The node coordinates are stored in each node as `.x` and `.y`.
    

---

### üß© Where Deck.gl Comes In

To replicate this layout in Deck.gl, you would:

- Extract `{ id, x, y, r, title, ... }` from the `HierarchyNode[]` after the D3 pack layout.
    
- Feed it into a `ScatterplotLayer` or `TextLayer`.
    

---

### ‚úÖ What You Asked Before

You asked for two options:

1. **Use layout algorithms (like ForceAtlas2)** ‚Üí to simulate natural clustering.
    
2. **Use already existing coordinates** ‚Üí from the current D3 `pack()` layout.
    

You can do both:

- Compute and export the D3-assigned `{ id, x, y, r }` layout as a JSON ‚Üí for rendering in Deck.gl.
    
- Later, generate ForceAtlas2 layout from the same data for comparison.
    

---

Would you like me to:

- Write a script to extract the existing D3 layout (`x`, `y`, `r`) from your current `papers2.json` after it's processed?
    
- Or should I go straight into generating ForceAtlas2 coordinates?
    

You choose ‚ú®

##### You said:

both

###### ChatGPT said:

D3 Node Coordinates

Unable to display visualization

The current data file (`papers2.json`) does **not** contain precomputed coordinates (`x`, `y`, or `r`) for any nodes.

This confirms that the layout in your current UI is being **computed dynamically in the browser using D3.js**, specifically via the [`d3.pack`](https://github.com/d3/d3-hierarchy#pack) layout algorithm. This is invoked here:

ts

CopyEdit

`pack<TreeNode>()   .size([3840, 2160])   (rootNode);`

This function computes `x`, `y`, and `r` in-place, after calling `rootNode.sum(...)`. These values are **not stored in the JSON** but exist in memory during runtime.

If you'd like to persist them (e.g. for Deck.gl), you'll need a script that:

1. Recreates the D3 hierarchy and pack layout in Node.js or Python.
    
2. Writes the resulting `x`, `y`, `r` back into a JSON structure.
    

Would you like me to create that export script next?

notes.title: ontoverse + agents
notes.excerpt: You said: OkSo what i want is to write an article on how agents can be used to extract knowledge from a knowledge graph, is there many research
notes.content:
###### You said:
OkSo what i want is to write an article on how agents can be used to extract knowledge from a knowledge graph, is there many research in the topic already?

###### ChatGPT said:

Yes, there is a growing body of research on using agents to extract knowledge from knowledge graphs (KGs).¬†This field is expanding rapidly, especially with the integration of large language models (LLMs) and multi-agent systems.¬†These approaches are being applied to tasks such as knowledge graph enrichment, reasoning, and natural language interaction.[Wikipedia+1arXiv+1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KnetMiner?utm_source=chatgpt.com)[arXiv+1arXiv+1](https://arxiv.org/html/2410.11531v1?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

---

### üîç Key Research Directions

#### 1. Multi-Agent Systems for Knowledge Graph Enrichment

Recent frameworks like¬†**KARMA**¬†employ multiple LLM-based agents to automate the enrichment of KGs.¬†These agents handle tasks such as entity discovery, relation extraction, schema alignment, and conflict resolution.¬†In experiments on 1,200 PubMed articles, KARMA identified over 38,000 new biomedical entities with an 83.1% correctness rate and reduced conflict edges by 18.6%¬†.[Oxford Academic+11arXiv+11LinkedIn+11](https://arxiv.org/abs/2502.06472?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

#### 2. Interactive Platforms for Knowledge Management

**AGENTiGraph**¬†is an interactive platform that integrates multiple AI agents to enhance interactions with KGs.¬†It allows for natural language interaction, knowledge extraction, integration, and real-time visualization, effectively bridging LLMs and KGs¬†.[arXiv+5TOPVIEW.AI+5arXiv+5](https://www.topview.ai/blog/detail/seven-ai-agents-and-a-knowledge-graph-agentigraph?utm_source=chatgpt.com)[TOPVIEW.AI+2arXiv+2arXiv+2](https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.11531?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

#### 3. Agent-Based Knowledge Graph Augmentation

Systems like¬†**DeepSeek**¬†utilize specialized agents for tasks such as document retrieval, summarization, relationship extraction, and evaluation.¬†These agents work collaboratively to augment KGs by processing new AI research papers, with a central controller coordinating their actions¬†.[LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/deekseek-ai-agents-knowledge-graph-augmentation-query-kai-xin-thia-tjfkc?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

#### 4. Graph Retrieval-Augmented Generation (GraphRAG)

**GraphRAG**¬†extends the concept of retrieval-augmented generation by incorporating knowledge graphs.¬†This approach allows models to connect disparate pieces of information, synthesize insights, and understand summarized semantic concepts over large data collections¬†.[Medium+3Reddit+3Wikipedia+3](https://www.reddit.com/r/LLMDevs/comments/1j0ca03/graphiti_knowledge_graph_agent_memory_gets_custom/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)[Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prompt_engineering?utm_source=chatgpt.com)

---

### üß† Core Agent Capabilities in Knowledge Graphs

- **Entity and Relation Extraction**:¬†Identifying and extracting entities and their relationships from unstructured data.[Reddit](https://www.reddit.com/r/LLMDevs/comments/1j0ca03/graphiti_knowledge_graph_agent_memory_gets_custom/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)
    
- **Schema Alignment**:¬†Ensuring that new information fits within the existing structure of the KG.
    
- **Conflict Resolution**:¬†Detecting and resolving inconsistencies within the KG.[arXiv+3arXiv+3arXiv+3](https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.12876?utm_source=chatgpt.com)
    
- **Natural Language Querying**:¬†Allowing users to interact with KGs using natural language.[TOPVIEW.AI+1arXiv+1](https://www.topview.ai/blog/detail/seven-ai-agents-and-a-knowledge-graph-agentigraph?utm_source=chatgpt.com)
    
- **Real-Time Visualization**:¬†Providing dynamic visual representations of the KG for better understanding and analysis.[arXiv+6arXiv+6arXiv+6](https://arxiv.org/abs/2206.14268?utm_source=chatgpt.com)
    

---

### üìù Suggested Structure for Your Article

1. **Introduction**:¬†Discuss the importance of knowledge graphs and the role of agents in extracting and managing knowledge.[SmythOS](https://smythos.com/ai-agents/ai-tutorials/building-a-knowledge-graph/?utm_source=chatgpt.com)
    
2. **Background**:¬†Provide an overview of knowledge graphs and the challenges in extracting knowledge from them.
    
3. **Agent-Based Approaches**:¬†Detail the various agent-based systems and frameworks, such as KARMA and AGENTiGraph.[arXiv+5arXiv+5arXiv+5](https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.11531?utm_source=chatgpt.com)
    
4. **Applications**:¬†Explore real-world applications of these systems in domains like biomedical research and AI development.
    
5. **Challenges and Future Directions**:¬†Discuss the current limitations and potential future developments in this field.
    
6. **Conclusion**:¬†Summarize the key points and the significance of agent-based knowledge extraction from KGs.

If you need assistance in drafting specific sections or require more detailed information on any of these topics, feel free to ask!

##### You said:

I want to publish in nature. I want to focus it on biomedical research, more specifically on drug discovery, suggest some approaches

###### ChatGPT said:

Publishing an article in¬†**Nature**¬†requires presenting a compelling, novel approach with clear biomedical relevance, especially in drug discovery. Given your interest in leveraging¬†**agent-based knowledge extraction**¬†from knowledge graphs (KGs), you should propose innovative, impactful applications that specifically address major bottlenecks in drug discovery.

Here's a detailed, structured suggestion for your article, tailored explicitly for publication in¬†**Nature**, emphasizing innovation, practical impact, and scientific rigor:

---

## üî¨ Suggested Article Focus and Structure

### ‚úÖ¬†**Working Title**

**"Accelerating Drug Discovery with Autonomous Agents in Knowledge Graph-Driven Biomedical Research"**

### üñãÔ∏è¬†**Abstract**

Describe the critical bottlenecks in drug discovery (such as identifying novel targets, predicting adverse drug reactions, or patient stratification). Propose the use of autonomous AI agents integrated with biomedical knowledge graphs as a transformative solution, highlighting your novel methodological contributions and potential to significantly accelerate drug discovery.

---

## üåê¬†**Article Outline and Approaches**

### 1.¬†**Introduction**

- Brief overview of drug discovery bottlenecks (e.g., cost, failure rates, time).
    
- Introduce knowledge graphs (KGs) as foundational infrastructure in biomedical research.
    
- Present your hypothesis: Autonomous agent-based approaches significantly enhance KG utility, accelerating drug discovery.
    

### 2.¬†**Background: Biomedical Knowledge Graphs**

- Brief review of existing KGs in biomedical contexts (e.g., Bio2RDF, Hetionet, Open Targets Platform).
    
- Limitations: manual maintenance, incomplete data integration, lack of dynamic updates.
    

### 3.¬†**Conceptual Framework: Agents for Knowledge Extraction**

- Explain clearly how AI agents differ from traditional methods (automation, autonomy, collaboration, adaptability).
    
- Highlight core capabilities relevant to drug discovery:
    
    - **Novel Target Identification**
        
    - **Biomarker Discovery**
        
    - **Drug Repurposing**
        
    - **Adverse Reaction Prediction**
        

### 4.¬†**Novel Methodological Approaches**

Propose at least two detailed, innovative methodologies that clearly illustrate your scientific novelty:

#### üß©¬†**Approach A: Autonomous Agent-Based Discovery of Novel Drug Targets**

- Autonomous agents systematically scan vast biomedical literature and omics databases.
    
- Agents utilize deep reinforcement learning to prioritize and validate potential targets.
    
- Demonstrate an example pipeline:
    
    - **Agent 1 (Entity Extraction)**: mines literature and clinical trial databases.
        
    - **Agent 2 (Knowledge Integration)**: aligns entities with existing KG schema.
        
    - **Agent 3 (Validation & Prioritization)**: evaluates evidence levels and ranks new targets using machine learning models.
        

#### üß©¬†**Approach B: Agent-Driven Personalized Drug Repurposing**

- Multi-agent system continuously updates patient-specific knowledge graphs with real-time patient data and genetic information.
    
- Agents predict effective repurposing candidates based on integrated genetic and clinical evidence.
    
- Agents leverage advanced models (e.g., graph neural networks, large language models trained on biomedical literature) for high-accuracy recommendations.
    

### 5.¬†**Case Studies or Proof-of-Concepts**

- Demonstrate preliminary results on:
    
    - Identification of novel therapeutic targets or biomarkers in oncology or rare diseases.
        
    - Prediction of successful drug repurposing scenarios validated by literature or clinical trials.
        
- Show clear metrics (accuracy, precision, recall) to prove your system's advantage over existing methods.
    

### 6.¬†**Discussion and Challenges**

- Discuss practical challenges in implementation: data quality, integration issues, computational efficiency, ethical and regulatory concerns.
    
- Explore solutions: multi-agent conflict resolution, explainability methods for AI decisions, ethical frameworks for agent accountability.
    

### 7.¬†**Future Perspectives**

- Vision for integrating agent-based systems into routine drug discovery workflows.
    
- Potential for collaborative international biomedical research frameworks.
    

### 8.¬†**Conclusion**

- Summarize significant advantages of your novel agent-based methodologies.
    
- Emphasize transformative potential to streamline and enhance the effectiveness of biomedical research and drug discovery processes.
    

---

## üñ•Ô∏è¬†**Novelty & Impact for Nature**

- Clearly position your work as transformative and highly innovative, essential criteria for Nature.
    
- Highlight the interdisciplinary nature (combining AI, bioinformatics, drug discovery).
    
- Provide strong proof-of-concept or early-stage validation to demonstrate feasibility and promise.
    

---

## üìñ¬†**Relevant Resources to Cite**

To further strengthen your case, reference recent literature and cutting-edge initiatives such as:

- **KARMA Framework**: Autonomous multi-agent KG enrichment.
    
- **Hetionet**: KG for drug repurposing.
    
- **Open Targets Platform**: Genomics-driven target validation using integrated KGs.
    
- Recent advances in¬†**Deep Reinforcement Learning**¬†and¬†**Graph Neural Networks**¬†for biomedical knowledge representation.
    

---

## üöÄ¬†**Next Steps**

- Develop a clear prototype or conceptual validation.
    
- Prepare engaging visualizations to illustrate your agent-driven KG architecture.
    
- Consider collaborating with experimentalists or clinical validation teams for strong proof-of-concept demonstrations.
    

If you'd like further guidance on specific sections, prototyping suggestions, or literature reviews, please let me know!

##### You said:

which dataset should I use? the whole pubmed?

###### ChatGPT said:

Using the¬†**entire PubMed database**¬†is ambitious but may not be practical initially due to computational demands and complexity. Instead, you should select specific, manageable, and highly relevant datasets to clearly demonstrate your agent-based methodology. Here are recommended approaches:

---

### üìå¬†**Recommended Datasets (Practical and Relevant):**

#### 1.¬†**PubMed Central Open Access Subset**

- **Description:**  
    ~8 million freely accessible full-text biomedical articles. Ideal for text mining, entity extraction, and relationship extraction.
    
- **Why Choose This?**  
    Excellent starting point‚Äîlarge enough to be impactful, small enough to be manageable.
    
- **Link:**  
    [PubMed Central Open Access Subset](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/tools/openftlist/)
    

---

#### 2.¬†**DrugBank**

- **Description:**  
    Detailed, structured knowledge of drug compounds, targets, pharmacological data, and interactions.
    
- **Why Choose This?**  
    Perfect for validating knowledge graph integration, target identification, and drug repurposing scenarios.
    
- **Link:**  
    DrugBank
    

---

#### 3.¬†**ChEMBL Database**

- **Description:**  
    Bioactivity data for over 2 million compounds against targets, including drug efficacy, chemical structures, and clinical data.
    
- **Why Choose This?**  
    Highly structured, reliable data‚Äîexcellent for agent-based knowledge enrichment.
    
- **Link:**  
    ChEMBL Database
    

---

#### 4.¬†**BioGRID**

- **Description:**  
    Interaction data (protein-protein, genetic) for understanding molecular mechanisms underlying drug interactions.
    
- **Why Choose This?**  
    Useful to demonstrate reasoning capabilities and relationship extraction.
    
- **Link:**  
    [BioGRID](https://thebiogrid.org/)
    

---

#### 5.¬†**Open Targets Platform**

- **Description:**  
    Integrated datasets covering target-disease relationships from genetics, genomics, drug evidence, and clinical trials.
    
- **Why Choose This?**  
    Specifically designed for drug discovery, directly aligned with your goal.
    
- **Link:**  
    Open Targets Platform
    

---

### üî¨¬†**Recommended Dataset Combinations (Ideal for Nature):**

|**Scenario**|**Datasets to Combine**|**Use Case**|
|---|---|---|
|**Novel Target Discovery**|PubMed Central OA + Open Targets Platform|Extraction, integration, validation|
|**Drug Repurposing**|DrugBank + ChEMBL + PubMed OA|Entity linking, relationship extraction|
|**Adverse Drug Reaction Prediction**|BioGRID + DrugBank + ChEMBL|Interaction prediction and validation|

---

### ‚ö†Ô∏è¬†**Why Not the Whole PubMed?**

- **Computationally Intensive**: The full dataset (>36 million articles) requires substantial computational power and resources.
    
- **Time-consuming preprocessing**: Significant preprocessing (OCR errors, text normalization, parsing errors) required.
    
- **Complexity**: Large-scale integration can obscure initial clarity and impact unless explicitly necessary.
    

Starting with the¬†**PubMed Central Open Access subset**¬†ensures feasibility and impactful demonstration of your methodology. As you validate your methods, scaling up to larger subsets or full datasets can become feasible as a follow-up step.

---

### üöÄ¬†**Suggested Initial Approach (for a Nature article)**:

- **Phase 1**: Develop and validate your methodology using PubMed Central OA subset combined with DrugBank or ChEMBL.
    
- **Phase 2**: After validation, scale the approach to larger PubMed subsets or integrate with Open Targets Platform for comprehensive validation and robustness checks.
    

---

Would you like more details or help setting up a specific workflow?

notes.excerpt: vocabulary resounding rotundo inability incapacity rebellious conscientious leap leapt leapt stand stood stood beggars mendigos mistook confundi (past) overtake superar worn off to gradually decrease, disappear, or stop
notes.content:
### vocabulary
resounding - rotundo
inability - incapacity
rebellious - conscientious
leap - leapt- leapt
stand- stood- stood
beggars - mendigos
mistook - confundi (past)
overtake - superar
worn off - to gradually decrease, disappear, or stop
uphold - by upholding an idea or tradition you show support it by what you say or do
gruelling - agotador/a
swirling (storm) - arremolinandose
cluttered with clothes - la habitacion esta cubierto de ropa
stuffy - mal ventilado
dingy - informal dirty
The prices are steep - very high
An upmarket part of town - where rich people live
scarcely - apenas
laughter = laugh - risa
downpour - lluvia torrencial
upbringing -educacion/crianza
strident  
### expressions 
might/may as well (car is broken, we might as well walk)
Upon his return, ...
she has sooner have been home - hubiera preferido estar en casa
recommend obtaining
So much the better
As indeed
Surely comes a close
Not by a long way
Helps me **unwind** when I‚Äôm feeling stressed
I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôd **entrust** my precious car to you
I‚Äôve always **mistrusted** politicians
We might well need your help later - There‚Äôs a strong chance.
There are bound to be a few problems - strong prediction
We mainly use the adjective ‚Äòcross‚Äô (= ‚Äòangry‚Äô) when talking to or about children. 
In a ‚Äòheated‚Äô argument, people allow their emotions to show
If you ‚Äò**get worked up**‚Äô, you become angry over a period of time
We mainly use the adjective ‚Äò**irate**‚Äô (= ‚Äòvery angry‚Äô) to describe formal situations, like a customer who is angry (but still polite) after receiving bad service
An ‚Äò**outburst**‚Äô of temper is when somebody expresses their anger suddenly and strongly. 
If you‚Äôre ‚Äòseething with anger‚Äô, you are very angry but try not to show it.

### Prepositions
Put you **at** a disadvantage
purpose **in** life
I was useless **at** managing other people
It¬¥s probably **to** your advantage
Is today¬¥s meeting happening **for** a purpose?
fall out - discutir
spark **off** a huge row
disrespect **for**
agreed **to** drive me
protest **against** doing something
insist **on** doing something
object **to** doing something
argue **against/ for** doing something

notes.title: 20251016 Interview 2
notes.excerpt: AI summary (Raw notes + transcript) Use Case Interview Summary Team: Computational Chemistry (Andrey Frolov & Christian Tyrchan) Date: [insert date] Attendees: Andrey Frolov, Christian Tyrchan, Richard Andersson,
notes.content:
### AI summary (Raw notes + transcript)
  
   Use Case Interview Summary

**Team:** Computational Chemistry (Andrey Frolov & Christian Tyrchan)  
**Date:** [insert date]  
**Attendees:** Andrey Frolov, Christian Tyrchan, Richard Andersson, Laura Lopez-Real

#### üéØ Objective

Understand the Computational Chemistry team‚Äôs current compute environment, workflows, and pain points ‚Äî particularly in relation to GPU access, simulation workloads, and potential fit for **Polaris** or future HPC/GPU infrastructure.
#### 1. **Team Overview & Focus**

- The group runs **molecular dynamics (MD)** and **computational chemistry simulations** at scale.
    
- Primary focus: accelerating simulations for protein systems and drug-like molecules.
    
- **Key challenge:** limited GPU compute capacity; most workloads currently run on CPU clusters.
    
- They use **>100 open-source chemistry tools**, not internally developed.

**Current Compute Environment**

|Component|Details|
|---|---|
|**Hardware**|Mix of ARM-based CPUs and x86 Unix machines|
|**GPU Resources**|~40 GPUs locally; AWS cluster with 200‚Äì400 GPUs (on-demand)|
|**CPU Utilization**|~90% usage ‚Äî they try to parallelize workloads across CPU nodes|
|**HPC Environment**|Use of **Scientific Compute Platform (SCP)** modules for simulation tools|
|**Storage**|~2 TB per user quota; total departmental capacity ~100 TB ‚Üí frequently run out of space|
|**Compute Nodes**|Dedicated Unix machines for main workflows|
|**Cluster Management**|Limited DevOps practices; no complex orchestration pipeline|
|**External Compute**|Pilot testing AWS-based HPC for large jobs|
**Software Stack & Tooling**

- Rely primarily on **open-source simulation tools** available as modules in the **SCP**.
    
- Example tools include molecular dynamics, quantum chemistry, and structure analysis packages (not developed in-house).
    
- Use of **Promox** (internal or related) ‚Äî explored by postdocs for performance acceleration.
    
- Software environment and dependencies managed through SCP modules, with minimal containerization or DevOps automation.
4. **Performance & Computational Bottlenecks**

- **Current limitation:** insufficient GPU power to train or run large models efficiently.
    
- **Workaround:** parallelization across CPUs, though this scales poorly for large simulations.
    
- **Potential breakthrough:** if simulations could be GPU-accelerated effectively, training times could be reduced from _months to weeks_ for microsecond-scale trajectories.
    
- **Utilization goal:** maintain near-100% GPU/CPU usage for cost efficiency (‚Äúevery last drop‚Äù).
    

---

5. **Workflow Summary**
- Simulations and modeling are typically executed via SCP modules or Unix scripts.
    
- Data handled manually; limited automation or CI/CD practices.
    
- No mention of Slurm or similar job schedulers ‚Äî workflows are relatively flat and team-driven.
    
- Postdocs are often engaged in exploring optimization techniques or new simulation pipelines.

5. **Data Characteristics**
- Simulation data sizes range from several GBs to multiple TBs per project.
- Larger systems (e.g., membrane proteins) require significantly more time and space.
    
- **Typical throughput:**
    
    - Small proteins ‚Üí ~500 ns/day
        
    - Larger systems ‚Üí 50‚Äì200 ns/day
        
    - Targeting microsecond-scale simulations (currently take _months_).
        

7. **Polaris & Future Alignment**
- Open to leveraging **GPU-based compute** for simulation acceleration and ML model training.
    
- Would benefit from:
    
    - **Multi-GPU job support** and elastic scaling.
        
    - **Simplified data management** and quota expansion.
        
    - **Centralized access** to pre-installed open-source chemistry libraries.
        
- They are **ideal early adopters** for GPU-intensive simulation workloads in Polaris.
    
üí° Key Insights / Opportunities

|Area|Observation|Potential Next Step|
|---|---|---|
|**Compute Power**|CPU-heavy environment; limited GPUs|Enable GPU-based simulation queue in Polaris|
|**Data Storage**|Departmental space limit (100 TB) reached frequently|Expand storage or connect to scalable S3-compatible system|
|**DevOps Maturity**|Minimal automation|Provide reusable workflow templates or managed pipelines|
|**Open-Source Tools**|Heavy reliance on external software|Pre-package key chemistry modules in Polaris environment|
|**Performance Goals**|Aim to shorten simulation cycles by 3‚Äì4√ó|Benchmark GPU-accelerated simulations on Polaris test nodes|

üß© Summary Quote (from transcript)

> ‚ÄúFor relatively small proteins, we can reach ~500 ns/day ‚Äî but large systems with membranes take months. If we could bring that down to weeks, it would be massive.‚Äù
  
### Raw notes
**Andrey Frolov and Christian Tyrchan**

Arm based cpu

90% CPU

Now they need GPU

They have 40 GPUs

They try to parallelise in CPU

They have a an AWS cluster with 200-400 GPUs

They have over 100 chemical tools

Many different softwares to run simulations


These tools are not developed internally and they are open source. Christian says that AZ has not enough computational power to train models.

  

Currently they use programs that are available in the SCP as modules that they can load

Promox - There are some postdocs working on these simulations, in case they can speed the training, it would be pretty disrupting

  

They dont have a very complex devops workflow

They have 3 main places where they run their workflows

- Dedicated Unix machines

  

2T of space per user, they have 100T for the whole department and they often run out space.

  

AZ Serve

notes.content:
**Innocenti:** No more CUDA out-of-memory errors. That sounds like a challenge. Well then.  
**Kumar:** Yeah.

notes.title: Cherry's Feedback on Ragify Solution Blueprint
notes.excerpt: RAGIFY review Approving Ragify architecture including the MCP service would mean that enterprise architecture supports the library as a pattern, which we actually don't. It is okay for
notes.content:
**RAGIFY** review 
- Approving Ragify architecture including the MCP service would mean that enterprise architecture supports the library as a pattern, which we actually don't.
- It is okay for exploration.
- AI Architecture is exploring more enterprise scalable options for MCP and A2A (is an API and AWS Bedrock AgentCore)
- AWS bedrock is an enterprise platform (foundation models, agents, LLM gateway, etc)
- Mulesoft is an API Gateway, they have a new product named AgentForce with similar capabilities to agentcore and we are exploring it

notes.title: Ragify Diaries
notes.excerpt: Friday 27th June: We have a meeting where we agreed to progress with the blueprint, but some decissions needed to be made. A draft of the blueprint was
notes.content:
Friday 27th June:
We have a meeting where we agreed to progress with the blueprint, but some decissions needed to be made. A draft of the blueprint was provided.

Tuesday 30th June:
I share with them information about the process to request access to GenAI models (a.k.a GenAI process, https://confluence.astrazeneca.com/pages/viewpage.action?spaceKey=AIS&title=Generative+AI+Process+Guidance), and how different cloud vendors work

Tuesday 1st July:
They ask me for the diagram and I send it to them, including text with the decissions that need to be made regarding including whether they want to cover the access to the GenAI models.

Wednesday 2nd July:
Working on the blueprint. 
I have asked them who is responsible of what so I can raise the eRID.

notes.title: 2025-06-27, Friday
notes.excerpt: Ragify blueprint questions for AI platforms team: 1. I need the link to the official Jira and confluence pages/ GH Pages and GH Issues. 2. We need to
notes.content:
## Ragify blueprint questions for AI platforms team:

1. I need the link to the official Jira and confluence pages/ GH Pages and GH Issues.
2. We need to agree on whether we want one vs. several blueprints (one for the python library, and a separate one for the Ragify services).
3. Need to clarify the following information
	1. How will the Solution be Serviced in BAU, and does the Service Design meet the requirements for a Minimal Viable Service? 
	2. Is this delivered as a service or as part of Platform delivery? 
	3. Has ‚ÄòAcceptance to Service‚Äô been involved? Are there any changes to existing Services?  
	4. Names of teams who would be supporting the solution. Please clarify if multiple teams are involved and which solution components are supported by which team(s)._ (2.10)
4. Who is going to register the application in Service Now?
	1. This is required for section 3.2 of the blueprint:
5. Who is going to own the process of PIA and RID?
	1. PIA
		- According to this page we won't require to raise a PIA for Ragify: https://confluence.astrazeneca.com/display/AIS/Generative+AI+Process+Guidance
		- ![[Pasted image 20250627141509.png]]
		- Note the sentence: **"If your project will not involve any personal data processing you will¬†not¬†need to raise a PIA."**
	2. Risk Impact Determination (RID)
		1. **Important dependency**: To raise a RID it is important to have the application registered in SNOW.
		2. https://astrazeneca-eqv.veevavault.com/ui/#doc_info/1104855/12/0?state_type=steady_state__v&anQS=page3&annotate=false this is the SOP for RID
		3. This is the application portal: https://azcollaboration.sharepoint.com/sites/TSC241/Pages/HomePage.aspx
	
**Actions for Laura**
- Initiate cyber security analysis
- Document the Architecture decisions on the Architecture Decision Log

notes.title: Domino Data Connectors
notes.excerpt: üßæ What is iDAP? Integrated Data Analysis Platform iDAP is an internal AstraZeneca framework designed to: Request , provision , and govern access to clinical and research datasets.
notes.content:
### üßæ What is iDAP? **Integrated Data Analysis Platform**

**iDAP** is an internal AstraZeneca framework designed to:

- **Request**, **provision**, and **govern access** to clinical and research datasets.
    
- Provide a **controlled and auditable environment** for data analytics.
    
- Serve as the **gateway** through which users (e.g., data scientists, statisticians) request access to clinical datasets from the R&D Data Lake.
    

### üîç iDAP in practice:

- A user submits an **iDAP request** specifying what data they need and what tool they will use (e.g., Domino).
    
- The **Data Provisioning Office (DPO)** fulfills the request by copying the required data (e.g., clinical SAS datasets) from **S3 buckets** into **Domino Datasets**.
    
- The request is associated with a unique **iDAP number** (e.g., `INT-20250303-1847`), which is used to track and audit provisioning.
    

### üß† Why is iDAP important?

- Ensures **compliance** with regulatory and privacy standards when accessing sensitive R&D data.
    
- Provides a **structured workflow** for provisioning and access control.
    
- Supports **traceability** through audit logs and naming conventions.
## üß± **Data Plane**

### ‚úÖ What is the Data Plane?

**Data Plane** refers to a **governed cloud-based layer for secure access to R&D datasets** at AstraZeneca. It enables:

- **Fine-grained, secure access** to data in AWS S3 buckets (clinical, omics, real-world data, etc.).
    
- **Credential management via IAM roles** to support tools like Domino, EWF, and others.
    
- **Centralized logging, security policies, and access rotation**.
    

### üîó Relevance to Domino

- Domino connects to **Data Plane** when provisioning data from S3 buckets.
    
- Future roadmap includes **direct integration**, allowing Domino to query or read from S3 via IAM roles **without manual key management**.
    
- Supports **scalability, automation, and compliance** (e.g., auto-rotating credentials, audit trail enforcement).

## üîê **EWF ‚Äì Enterprise Workbench Framework**

### ‚úÖ What is EWF?

**EWF** stands for **Enterprise Workbench Framework**, an internal AstraZeneca platform that:

- Provides **governed access to analytics tools**, including SAS, R, Python, and cloud notebooks.
    
- Acts as a **centralized access and execution layer** for secure, compliant analytical work.
    
- Is used widely across clinical and biometrics functions.
    
### üîó Relevance to Domino

- Users often want to **move workflows or datasets from EWF to Domino** to take advantage of more scalable or cloud-native tools (e.g., ML workflows, Jupyter notebooks, model training).
    
- Integration between **EWF ‚Üí Domino** is not yet available (marked TBD in your roadmap) and is considered a **complex integration** due to:
    
    - Different authentication models
        
    - Audit trail requirements
        
    - Data residency and compliance
